Posts.Title: Can't straighten my arm after chemo katie31 exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2012 12:51AM myangels wrote: I'm sorry you're going through a stressful time. The elevated blood work could mean a number of things. You mentioned about fatty liver. I have that too and there are times my liver enzymes are elevated. I could do blood work again the following month and they are back to normal. Many of the meds we all take can also elevate the enzyme level, especially those that contain Tylenol. Try not to go into full panic mode until you speak with your onc. There are so many meds and treatments. Sometimes it's just watching the foods we eat. Keep going forward and be well. Rose
Posts.Title: If it's not ine thing it's always something else stellaratovsky stellaratovsky

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2012 04:07PM myangels wrote: Lynne,  I'm sorry to hear about your progression. I had a similiar experience when I was on the Zometa trial. I had no SE, didn't have pain, and I felt pretty good. After I had my bone scan done, it showed that I had increased uptake activity! So, I know how you feel, how could such a negative report be possible...I had no symptoms! Right after that, my onc  took me off Zometa and started me on Xgeva. We'll see what the next bone scan reveals. Lynne, maybe you should have a meeting with your onc to discuus the pros and cons of some of the other chemo drugs he has in mind. If you're still unsure about your decision, I would leave it up to him.  Good luck to you...caring thoughts and prayers coming your way. Rose

Help her live her life To the fullest. Please promote her And cause her to excel Above her expectations. Help her to shine In the darkest places Where it is impossible To love. Protect her at all times, Lift her up when she needs You the most, And Let her know when She walks with you, She will always Be safe. Love you Girl! Do not ask the Lord to guide your footsteps if you are not willing to move your feet. Posts.Content: May 15, 2012 02:35AM myangels wrote: Hi there,  Do you have any bone mets? I'm 2 years in with my dx and had bone mets from the get-go. I have multiple sites, one of which is in the sacral area. I was on Zometa but it didn't work, so my onc put me on Xgeva. I also take Arimidex. After my 1st and 2nd injections, it felt like my lower back was getting worse. Sometimes I know that different meds are working in the bones, and perhaps that was what I was feeling. I'm taking Tramadol 100 mg every 6hrs. and that does help to keep my pain under control. There's so many meds out there, and I'm sure you will be able to get on something thats controlling your discomfort. Good luck to you, you're in my thoughts. Rose

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2012 02:15PM myangels wrote: Hi Cate,  First of all I want to welcome you to this club that none of us want to be members of. I get your feelings...such a mixed bag it's mind boggling! You asked if you'll ever feel alittle better...you will, but it takes time. You have to give yourself time to get all this information straight in your head. Later on, you will see that you will go on with your life the best you can. This board has been such a lifesaver for me. I too have a family that is so supportive, but they can never really put themselves in this situation...thank God!    Cate, you will find that this board is a very special group of gals that are all going through the same feelings. Everyone here gets it. I'm so thankful that I found this forum...I don't feel alone anymore. This is truly a group that is so caring, compassionate, and supportive. Good luck to you. We are all here for you! Rose

I don't think anybody knows, there are so many factors with cancer. Right now I'm on Arimidex and Xgeva. Had chemo and radiation 2 years ago. I do have bad days with pain, anxiety, depression, but don't we all? I do have good days as well, when I'm out and about, doing my thing. It's hard not to focus on cancer, but I've found that if I keep busy enough it makes me feel better, physically and mentally, and I'm not thinking about cancer every minute. Rose

Posts.Title: Hip Pain Karen2012 camillegal

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2012 06:29PM myangels wrote: I am 2 years in with my stage IV breast cancer dx. My scans also showed many areas of my skeleton that the cancer had  metastasized. to. I was started on chemo first to shrink the breast tumors. This was followed by a bi-lateral mastectomy. After that, I started on my radiation regiman. I was recently taken off zometa infusions that I was getting every 12 weeks. This was because my last scans showed some "activity" to different areas of my skeleton that were already affected. My ONC then immediately started me on Xgeva which I receive every 4 weeks. I am 100% confident in my oncology team as I am with the center that I go to for my treatments. I believe you really have to be confident and trustworthy of your onc.Sounds like you aren't. I would run and not walk to get a 2nd opinion. Wish you luck and hope you get on an effective treatment plan soon. Let us know how you make out. God bless you. (((HUG!)))

Posts.Title: Hello, and how are you today, Ma'am? JillThut ma111

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2012 03:13AM myangels wrote: This happened years ago, and I tell the story to lots of people cause it's so funny! We had just moved from NYC to upstate NY. So beautiful, peaceful, and really getting into nature. One morning as I was looking out the window for the school bus for my sons, I couldn't believe it, but there had to be 30 very BIG cows blocking my driveway! What to do?? My husband heard somewhere that if you distract them with food, they'll just follow you till you place it down. He asked me what kind of food he should bring them. How the heck should I know, I don't have any cow food I responded. There was some left over spaghetti from last nights dinner: maybe I'll bring that hubby says. I looked at him and said I didn't think cows ate spaghetti! By this time, I noticed that now the school bus was coming up the road. So he grabbed the first thing he saw to lure the cows away from the driveway and make a path for the bus. What he grabbed was a loaf of italian bread! (remember we lived in NYC) He goes running up the driveway wildley waving this italian bread around. Well they moved alright....they all circled around him and he couldn't get out! Thank God the bus came and I started waving frantically for him to wait because my boys weren't up there yet. When I looked at the busdriver, he was laughing his head off watching this scene with my husband and the cows. He honked his horn a couple of times, and miraculously, the cows walked nonchalantly into the woods. I'm sure that story spread all over town. Just a funny memory...we still laugh about it today! Rose

Posts.Title: Stay-bill-ity DivineMrsM Jac53

Posts.Content: May 22, 2012 08:32PM myangels wrote: Angel,   Had my ups and downs. I have to say that I go to a wonderful place here in Arizona. It's the Mayo Clinic, I'm sure you've heard of it. I was so impressed on the level of professionalism and caring attitude. I started with chemo. I received that "red devil" chemo that kind of did me in. I wasn't nauseous or anything like that, but so tired...all I wanted to do was to lay down. The chem was followed by a bi-lateral mastectomy. I was diagnosed with cancer to my right breast, but I opted for removal of the left one too. Truthfully, my surgery wasn't as bad as I had anticipated. Those dam drains though were the most problematic! Six weeks after surgery I was scheduled to do my rounds of radiation. Other than having to be there everyday for my treatments, I really didn't have major complaints. So now, I'm taking Arimidex every day along with the Xgedva shot I get every 4 weeks. I was on the Zometa trial and thought I was doing pretty good until the scans came back and showed increased activity. So, now my onc wants me on the Xgeva, believes it's more superior to Zometa in prevention of bone complications. I have some moderate bone pain but with pain med. management it seems to be in control for now. Other days, well, I'm like a basket case. I get depressed and so anxious thinking about all of this that my brain is on overload! I don't know if you're spiritual or not, but I returned back to my faith after I got sick. It's been a great comfort to me and helps me to put things in perspective. Also, my wonderful, wonderful family have been with me every step of the way! I don't think I could have done this without them. You know...mu husband even took care of my drains and the yucky stuff that comes with the. I never thought in a million years that he would have the stomache to do this. So, I really try not to project a hundred steps ahead of me, just focusing on whats happening now. I think I wrote more than you wanted to know so I'll end here. One last thing,  be good to yourself!! Sending you hugs. Rose

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2012 05:59PM myangels wrote: Try warm soaks alternating with cold. Also, elevation. I hope you didn't fracture it, but even if you did, the treatment is limited. It really helps with the pain and the inflammation thats causing the pain. Hope you feel better! Rose

Posts.Title: And the crap news today is... alesta29 LauraOntario

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2012 10:30PM - edited Apr 15, 2012 10:37PM by myangels hi Cynthia, I was diagnosed with Stage lV with bone mets from the get-go. That was 2 years ago. During my course of chemo and other treatments, I could hardly walk so I opted to use a cane. My ONC said we'll try some radiation to the hip as that was the area it was stemming from and also one of the areas that I had mets to. Well, 2 days after the radiation, the severe pain in my hip vanished. Right now I'm taking Tramadol and Naproxyn for general pain and seems to be pretty effective.I also take Arimidex every day and just recently started on Xgeva, (was taken off Zometa) I hope it all turns out well for you so that you are comfortable and not in any severe pain. This cancer really sucks big time! I'm so glad I found this website, it's been so helpful and supportive!  (((HUGS)))!
Posts.Title: Why am I having trouble walking? (bone mets issue) Cynthia1962 Cynthia1962

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2012 03:28PM myangels wrote: Hi Elizabeth, I think that the fear is always with us. It's how we deal with it. I'm sorry to hear that you don't have a good support system. In my case, that has helped me so much. I'm 2 years in getting my stage IV diagnosis. I have bone mets all over the place. But I think I'm somewhat used to it now. My greatest fear now is that it just stays in the bones and doesn;t decide to go sight-seeing through the rest of my body. Are you a spiritual person? I turned back to God after my diagnosis. I now read the bible too. If someone told me this before I got sick I wouldn't believe it. But now, for me, that has helped me to grow stronger both physically and spiritually. I still have my own private pity parties, but not as many. I still cry and think of the day I will have to leave my family. But all in all, right now, I'm really trying to live my life. We're going to Las Vegas for my birthday in May! You have to reward yourself now and then and do something out of the ordinary. And I continue to pray, every day. It really does help in strenthening my heart and my spirit. I will keep you in my thoughts and prayers. Here is one of my favorite quotes. I find it really encouraging and maybe it will be for you too: 'Ring the bells that can still ring Forget your perfect offering There is a crack in everything Thats how the light gets in." (((HUGS)))!

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2012 04:02AM myangels wrote: Seamstress,    Did you know that it's within your patient rights to request a female caregiver or RN to be in there with you during the procedure? Don't feel wierd about it, you do have the right to request a female to be in there with you.  Also, if your concerned that you'll be all exposed during the procedure...the only body parts that should be exposed are the body parts they're working on. Your legs and upper body should be covered. Rose
Posts.Title: Zapping ovaries with radiation seamstress myangels

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2012 11:16AM myangels wrote: Hi georgie,     Yes, definately follow through with the plan. I agree that perhaps you would seek a 2nd opinion if not comfortable with the 1st. One thing that I've learned during my "journey" is to feel completely confident with your medical team. Don't be afraid to ask questions if you don't understand something. STOP GOOGLING! I did the same thing and felt worse...not helpful. Good luck with your mammo and let us know how you make out. Sending caring thoughts your way! Rose
Posts.Title: Painful thickened Area in Breast...scared to death georgiehopper Sommer43

Posts.Content: May 21, 2012 02:49PM myangels wrote: Hi Anne,    Did your doc check you out for congestive heart failure? I know that this can be a major cause of swelling in the lower extremities. He may consider to place you on a diuretic such as lasix. In the meantime, keep your legs elevated and you may want to try TED stockings or A-E hose (anti-embolus). They're a real  pain in the ass to get on, but they seem to be really effective for swelling and prevention of blood clots. I hope your swelling gets better and be more comfortable. Rose

Posts.Title: I feel like my horse chele alesta29

Posts.Content: May 28, 2012 08:59PM myangels wrote: Hi Katie,   We all go through so many mixed emotions. One minute you could feel happy and the next you'll be in tears. This dam cancer just causes so much havoc...there are times I actually feel like I have dementia. I was out the other day having a pleasant time with my husband and we spotted a beautiful deer. I was mesmerized by it's beauty and freedom. Well, seconds later, I began to cry. The reason being is that I used to live upstate NY and we had a beautiful view of our woods and the deer that used to come right up to our back deck. This was also the time I refer to as my other life, the one when I was normal, the one that didn't have cancer in it. Thats why I was crying. Sorry, got off to a bit of a rant. But wanted to let you know that during my "journey??" I've seen that my perspectives and priorities have changed so much. I don't worry about silly things anymore, I focus all my energy on those that I love and thats my husband and my 2 grown sons. So Katie, put everything else aside and put all your attention on things that mean the most to you, like your precious daughter. Things have a way of getting back into some dimension of balance. Take care Katie. Have a wonderful time enjoying your daughter's birthday and being around those you love. Sending my thoughts and caring wishes your way!  Sorry again I started to get off on my rant. Rose

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2012 07:14PM myangels wrote: What happens now is to get started on your treatment regimen. I also have bone mets, mine is extensive. I'm also on Arimidex and xgeva that I get monthly. I have upcoming radiation treatments for pain that I've been having to my hip, leg, and sacral area. You should look at this as something uncureable, but certainly treatable. If one treatment doesn't work, move on to the next. Good luck to you and on your new treatment plan. Rose.

I know other people mean well but some of the comments makes me want to really go off on them. Recently, an older woman told me her saga of her miserable life and how she had pain from head to toe. She even had the nerve to ask "why doesn't God take me?" It took all I had to not jump all over her! My saving grace now  are my family and of course this stage IV forum where I know that all us gals can really support and encourage one another. Take care and be good to yourself. You are in my prayers. Rose
